description:
Plasmodium vinckei petteri is a species of malaria parasite that infects rodents, particularly certain species of mice and voles. It is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa and the genus Plasmodium.

Plasmodium vinckei petteri is characterized by its ability to invade and replicate within the red blood cells of its rodent host. The parasite has a complex life cycle that involves both sexual and asexual stages, including the formation of sporozoites, merozoites, and gametocytes.

This particular subspecies, P. vinckei petteri, was initially isolated from the African lion-tailed macaque (Macaca silenus) and has since been used extensively in research to study the biology and pathogenesis of malaria in rodent models. It is considered a useful tool for investigating various aspects of malaria, such as host-parasite interactions, immune responses, and the development of potential therapeutic interventions.
